context: Another family of bowlback mandolins came from <a0_0><b5_0>Milan and Lombardy<b5_0/><a0_0/>. These mandolins are closer to the <a1_0><b6_0>mandolino or mandore<b6_0/><a1_0/> than other modern mandolins. <a2_0>They are <b7_0>shorter and wider<b7_0/><a2_0/> than the standard Neapolitan mandolin, with a shallow back. The instruments have <a3_0><b8_0>6<b8_0/> strings<a3_0/>, 3 wire treble-strings and 3 gut or wire-wrapped-silk bass-strings. The strings ran between the tuning pegs and a bridge that was glued to the soundboard, as a guitar's. The Lombardic mandolins were tuned g b e' a' d" g". A developer of the Milanese stye was <a4_0><b9_0>Antonio Monzino<b9_0/><a4_0/> (Milan) and his family who made them for 6 generations.
